xxl.core.collections.sweepAreas
Class AbstractSAImplementor<E>

java.lang.Object
  xxl.core.collections.sweepAreas.AbstractSAImplementor<E>
All Implemented Interfaces:
SweepAreaImplementor<E>, MetaDataManageable<java.lang.Object,java.lang.Object>, MetaDataProvider<CompositeMetaData<java.lang.Object,java.lang.Object>>
Direct Known Subclasses:
BagSAImplementor, HashSAImplementor, ListSAImplementor
public abstract class AbstractSAImplementor<E>
extends java.lang.Object
implements SweepAreaImplementor<E>

A pre-implementation of the interface SweepAreaImplementor. It provides the basic code for the initialization of a SweepAreaImplementor as well as a default implementation of the retrieval functionality.

See Also:
SweepAreaImplementor, Predicate, Iterator

Field Detail

predicates

protected Predicate<? super E>[] predicates
Binary predicates used to query this implementor. To offer a retrieval depending on the ID passed to the query calls, an implementor requires such an array of predicates.
This array is set during the #initialize(int, Predicate[]) method.

ID

protected int ID
The ID of the SweepArea this implementor belongs to.
This ID is set during the #initialize(int, Predicate[]) method.

protected Predicate<? super E> equals

Method Detail

initialize

public void initialize(int ID,
                       Predicate<? super E>[] predicates,
                       Predicate<? super E> equals)
This method is used to initialize the implementor of a SweepArea. Commonly, it is invoked in the constructor of a SweepArea to inform the underlying implementor about the ID and the query-predicates of the corresponding SweepArea.

Specified by:
initialize in interface SweepAreaImplementor<E>
Parameters:
ID - The ID of the corresponding SweepArea.
predicates - The query-predicates of the corresponding SweepArea.
equals - The predicate used to determine equality of objects within the SweepArea.

query

public abstract java.util.Iterator<E> query(E o,
                                            int ID)
                                     throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
Queries this implementor with the help of the specified query object o and the query-predicates set during initialization, see method #initialize(int, Predicate[]). Returns all matching elements as an iterator.
Note: The returned iterator should not be used to remove any elements from this implementor!

Specified by:
query in interface SweepAreaImplementor<E>
Parameters:
o - The query object. This object is typically probed against the elements contained in this implementor.
ID - An ID determining from which input this method is triggered.
Returns:
All matching elements of this implementor are returned as an iterator.
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - Throws an IllegalArgumentException if something goes wrong due to the passed arguments during retrieval.

query

public java.util.Iterator<E> query(E[] os,
                                   int[] IDs,
                                   int valid)
                            throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
The default implementation is restricted to the probing with single elements by calling the method query(Object, int) on os[0] and IDs[0].

Specified by:
query in interface SweepAreaImplementor<E>
Parameters:
os - The query objects. These objects are typically probed against the elements contained in this implementor.
IDs - IDs determining from which input the query objects come from.
valid - Determines how many entries at the beginning of os and IDs are valid and therefore taken into account.
Returns:
All matching elements of this SweepArea are returned as an iterator.
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If valid is != 1.

filter

protected java.util.Iterator<E> filter(java.util.Iterator<? extends E> it,
                                       E o,
                                       int ID)
Returns a Cursor that results from filtering the passed iterator it with the query-predicate at position ID in the predicate array. Since the query-predicates are binary, the second argument (the right one) is fixed by setting it to the passed object o.
The same functionality could be achieved by applying a Filter to the iterator it. But in this case, the binary query-predicates have to be wrapped to unary ones using the class RightBind. However, the latter approach suffers from decreased efficiency since it doubles the number of method calls.

Parameters:
it - The iterator to be filtered.
o - Specifies the second (right) argument when the binary query-predicate is invoked.
ID - Determines the query-predicate. predicates[ID] is utilized for probing.
Returns:
A cursor that delivers all elements of the underlying iterator where predicates[ID].invoke(it.next(), o) holds.

filter

protected java.util.Iterator<E> filter(java.util.Iterator<? extends E> it,
                                       E[] os,
                                       int[] IDs,
                                       int valid)
